Review: 
Norfolk-based singer/songwriter Holly LerskiÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s new album The Wooden House is a true DIY affair: written, performed and recorded on a minimum of equipment by Holly at her home studio, or Ã¢â‚¬ËœshedÃ¢â‚¬â„¢, to give it its technical term (with a little help from friends James Ã¢â‚¬ËœHutchÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ Hutchinson on bass and producer/mixer Stu Hanna (Megson), this self- released collection of ten songs is possessed of a lightness of touch and an airy, spacious sound which make for an appealing and enjoyable listen. 
The songs are well-structured and supported, not overwhelmed, by either their arrangements or the production Ã¢â‚¬â€œ but the real star of the show is HollyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s voice: she has a clear, rounded range which is perfectly suited to her indie-folk material. 
The ukelele-driven Inkblot gets things off to a good start: lyrically, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a sad song for a lost love, bolstered by a sense of putting a brave face on things even though your heart is breaking. The Ã¢â‚¬Å“carry on regardlessÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ subtext is reinforced by a quiet, almost bittersweet musical arrangement, through which HollyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s multi-tracked harmony vocals shine as bright as uncried tears. 

The albumÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s title track Wooden House has a sweet, wistful feel and a hint of an Americana influence. James Ã¢â‚¬ËœHutchÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ Hutchinson adds some well-placed yet unobtrusive bass to counterpoint HollyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s banjo. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a highlight of the album, not least for its chorus, which is an insidiously hooky thing that youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll find yourself humming for hours. All in all this is a song with massive potential for Ã¢â‚¬â€œ if youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll excuse my lapse into DJ Smashy and Nicey territory Ã¢â‚¬â€œ heavy rotation in nationwide drivetime radio slots. 

HollyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s knack for catchy hooks again comes to the fore in Building You The Ark, particularly with the perfectly-placed multi-tracked call-and-response harmonies in the songÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s closing section. A syncopated acoustic guitar and quietly pattering rhythm section keep the song moving while its lyric of reassurance is tantalisingly ambiguous: Ã¢â‚¬Å“IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m building you the ark, youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be all rightÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½, she sings Ã¢â‚¬â€œ but to herself or to another?
